summary: 9-9-6-0: When all you build is character (5 minute read) The current AI gold rush is built on a dangerous gamble: trading "996" work weeks (9 am to 9 pm, 6 days a week) for a future lottery ticket. While VCs risk borrowed money, employees risk borrowed time - an asset that cannot be refunded. When the bubble inevitably bursts, many will face the "9-9-6-0" outcome: years of sacrifice that yielded zero dollars.

title: Your perfectionism is lying to you
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-01, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.unknownarts.co%2Fp%2Fyour-perfectionism-is-lying-to-you-2f9%3Futm_source=tldrfounders/1/0100019ada080d83-a5954e0d-379a-4a33-8921-78b14ee98fcd-000000/YHlODVP6lLnu1tErnz-LGs10ItfHtjU4XDD1pdots6s=433
summary: Your perfectionism is lying to you (4 minute read) We often mistake perfectionism for "high standards," but it is usually just procrastination wearing a tuxedo. The obsession with flawlessness prevents you from finishing. In creative work, completion is the only currency that matters. The most successful builders shift their goal from being "perfect" to being "prolific." You are not sculpting stone, you are planting a garden. The only way to get quality is to force yourself to ship quantity.

title: How prompt caching works
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-01, Reading time: 32 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fsankalp.bearblog.dev%2Fhow-prompt-caching-works%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019ada4b4439-aff2f619-7222-4e57-af02-10316792855b-000000/krlIMHWQHv3GyDdg0VkFKjrKsmblbpKk5EBesJ9gT0I=433
summary: How prompt caching works (32 minute read) Prompt caching works per-content, not per-conversation. Prefix caching works at the token level, not the request level, which is why it works across requests. Any change in the prefix breaks the entire hash chain.

title: Are we in a GPT-4-style leap that evals can't see?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-01, Reading time: 9 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fmartinalderson.com%2Fposts%2Fare-we-in-a-gpt4-style-leap-that-evals-cant-see%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019ada4b4439-aff2f619-7222-4e57-af02-10316792855b-000000/67wP6yAW-UaoZoI5vdrgDbkdRCR3GDWhvtboT5Yp_hg=433
summary: Are we in a GPT-4-style leap that evals can't see? (9 minute read) Chat is a terrible way to evaluate models. GPT-4 was so significantly better at answering questions that it was an obvious step forward. The industry needs to add more types of benchmarking. Models are currently being evaluated like students in an exam, but that's not representative of how the world works.

title: What makes a great ChatGPT app
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-01, Reading time: 10 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fdevelopers.openai.com%2Fblog%2Fwhat-makes-a-great-chatgpt-app%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019ada4b4439-aff2f619-7222-4e57-af02-10316792855b-000000/D6_4dRiUiLhMDOEK52oX1qOCanrL47eMHDelIKxQGaM=433
summary: What makes a great ChatGPT app (10 minute read) The biggest mistake developers make is trying to port entire products into ChatGPT when they should instead expose a few powerful capabilities the model can orchestrate mid-conversation. Devs should organize around giving ChatGPT new data it can't access ("know"), enable real actions like booking appointments or playing games ("do"), and present information through richer UI than text walls ("show").

title: Context plumbing
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-01, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Finterconnected.org%2Fhome%2F2025%2F11%2F28%2Fplumbing%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019ada4b4439-aff2f619-7222-4e57-af02-10316792855b-000000/UXOj34i22weCijRfmBo4hYuDAxyQkP_R7RmuQQ6j2F8=433
summary: Context plumbing (6 minute read) Context is always changing, as it is dynamic. The context is not always where the AI runs. To make an agent run really well, you need to move the context to where it needs to be. Agents shouldn't have to look up context for every single query, because that's slow. Engineers need to build pipes that continuously flow potential context from where it is created to where it is going to be used.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-02, Reading time: 11 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fcss-tricks.com%2Fon-inheriting-and-sharing-property-values%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019adef74ab5-0c40d54a-229b-4d9c-8654-94c3ded94534-000000/K_rVj0vNbrsDyZRFzakJfdQUuVn67B_3_30rszfYc-Q=433
summary: On Inheriting and Sharing Property Values (11 minute read) CSS doesn't let you set one property based on another's value (like `border-radius: height`), and there's no magic `compute()` function coming. Your best bets right now are to use CSS custom properties if you know the values, `aspect-ratio` to link width/height, `currentColor` to reuse colors, or container query units like `100cqh` to steal parent dimensions.

title: Rad

summary: Rad (GitHub Repo) Rad gives users Python-like scripting with CLI superpowers built in. It allows users to write maintainable scripts with declarative argument parsing, built-in JSON processing, and more. The project is still in early development, but it is already useful for real scripts. Rad is optimized for CLI scripting - a general-purpose language may be more appropriate for enterprise applications, high-performance computations, and projects that require specialized libraries.

title: How Can Interpretability Researchers Help AGI Go Well?

summary: How Can Interpretability Researchers Help AGI Go Well? (32 minute read) The Google DeepMind mechanistic interpretability team has pivoted to a pragmatic approach to interpretability over the last year. It is important to have empirical feedback on goals with good proxy tasks. Near-complete understanding isn't required for significant impact. Good focused projects start with a theory of change, and good exploratory projects start with a robustly useful setting.

title: 100,000 TPS over a billion rows: the unreasonable effectiveness of SQLite
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-03, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fandersmurphy.com%2F2025%2F12%2F02%2F100000-tps-over-a-billion-rows-the-unreasonable-effectiveness-of-sqlite.html%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/0100019ae41b5d32-e397873b-baf2-4ccb-8078-1dea7997e506-000000/5p6Upt28Il-7Bx3qRnQOTeDWUTTHs7JDYpEdqk-w02U=434
summary: 100,000 TPS over a billion rows: the unreasonable effectiveness of SQLite (8 minute read) SQLite can achieve extremely high transaction throughput on a single machine because eliminating network latency and using a single-writer model enables batching and efficient concurrency with readers. In contrast, network databases like Postgres hit hard limits from latency and contention, showing that SQLite's ‚Äúlimitations‚Äù are actually strengths for many real-world workloads.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-03, Reading time: 10 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fbun.com%2Fblog%2Fbun-joins-anthropic%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019ae4300932-43f46e76-9193-48d6-a96b-61cd31327356-000000/D_4V2LtM5GFjBxCSOiM8peZ9hPhHr1eXYuL2UITyjdA=434
summary: Bun is joining Anthropic (10 minute read) Bun, a high-performance JavaScript runtime, bundler, and package manager, has been acquired by Anthropic. This acquisition provides Bun with long-term stability and resources to focus on building the best JavaScript tooling, especially for AI-driven software like Claude Code. Bun will remain open-source, MIT-licensed, and developed in public on GitHub by the same team, with continued focus on Node.js compatibility and performance.

summary: Bet the farm (3 minute read) Many companies are bragging about wide-scale AI adoption, but their hallway conversations tell a different story: many employees haven't opened AI tools in weeks. Dashboards are showing logins, not usage. This is transformation theater. Companies that go all in on AI by making it mandatory tell a different story: increased revenue and lower headcount. The best people see the theater and leave for places where transformation is real.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-03, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2FuXDpsk/1/0100019ae45df0d5-1aae3acc-5d46-4738-88ae-d76ca28ebab4-000000/N5w6InUhboZrAvEYf_Ejw8vV0NIwGiuB0mDRUrIMmJw=434

title: Thoughts on AI progress
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-03, Reading time: 14 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.dwarkesh.com%2Fp%2Fthoughts-on-ai-progress-dec-2025%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019ae4942089-056b3ae6-4c19-4178-9a46-9bb0d0d00e42-000000/6XYmCW093kM3REYf07UTvX4djvVjvlPf7dQEaR0lRNg=434
summary: Thoughts on AI progress (Dec 2025) (14 minute read) The driver for further improvement will be continual learning. Solving continual learning will require incremental improvements, just like solving in-context learning. Labs will likely release something next year that they will call continual learning, but it will just be progress towards continual learning. Human-level continual learning may take another five to ten years of further progress.

title: Everyone in Seattle Hates AI
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-04, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fjonready.com%2Fblog%2Fposts%2Feveryone-in-seattle-hates-ai.html%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019ae91ab895-b78bfd10-8959-443c-a741-23741d22e204-000000/bPtVyLRStMWYeKuqyJNWnR6e6_6ZUlDmNgpoQPB3Pzg=434
summary: Everyone in Seattle Hates AI (6 minute read) Tech workers in Seattle tend to react negatively when the topic of AI is brought up. This is due to several reasons, like layoffs due to AI, the proliferation of AI in software, and being forced to use AI tools whether they work or not. The result is that engineers are no longer trying because they think they can't, and companies aren't empowering them because they assume they shouldn't. Bad products are only reinforcing the belief that AI is doomed.

summary: Getting from tested to battle-tested (20 minute read) Testing is essential when building reliable software. Being able to show that your code is correct and resilient can be hard, and it takes time to write good tests. In a non-trivial system, tests are an approximation at best, as the real world is messy. Going from being tested to being battle-tested requires learning some things that can only be learned through experience.

title: My Favorite Principle
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-04, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fcodestyleandtaste.com%2Fmy-favorite-principle.html%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019ae943e5e6-8ee22876-7dbe-493c-87e0-0533a99a9978-000000/cruwUeVxo0EecCsqP0uGjAHakE9J2yM_4hn6x7Sn6FU=434
summary: My Favorite Principle (4 minute read) "Levo's Principle" states that an object's behavior should remain constant after construction to improve code clarity, reduce bugs, and simplify refactoring. The main exception to this rule applies to procedural-style objects like stream parsers, where behavior changes are inherent to the object's purpose.

title: Should CSS be Constraints?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-12-04, Reading time: 10 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fpavpanchekha.com%2Fblog%2Fwhy-css-bad.html%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019ae943e5e6-8ee22876-7dbe-493c-87e0-0533a99a9978-000000/SlQlAoziyB1E4W373Xv642V9T01_5OOEKoyONWdUnAQ=434
summary: Should CSS be Constraints? (10 minute read) CSS layout rules are complex and hard to pick up just from examples. One commonly-proposed replacement for CSS is a constraint system. Rule-based systems can be complex and hard to predict, but it is almost impossible to create a layout that is not under- or over-determined. A better way to improve CSS would be to provide more intuitive rule systems with more predictable, less esoteric rules.
